UnitType.Quote: Kings may rule kingdoms, but only those in the shadows will know its secrets.
Kings may rule kingdoms, but only those in the shadows will know its secrets.

UnitType.Backstory: There are rumors of a powerful War Boar in the wild. According to the few that claim to have seen him he has destroyed outposts, chased Ogres from their lairs and emptied larders. They have taken to calling him Bonesplinter. Now whenever food goes missing or a building collapses Bonesplinter is blamed. But when soldiers arrive there is no sign of the beast. He may be a myth invented by fools, but we would be wise to watch out for him in case he is real.

The Pillars of Grazna were a set of powerful golems crafted by Morrigan the Mad out of the red stone of the Asrk Mountain. Unlike most golems they were not given specific areas to guard or instructions to follow. Morrigan's whims changed too frequently for that to be useful so he crafted figurines that allowed him to issue his ever changing commands. In Grazna, the movement of the Pillars was often the only indication that Morrigan had changed plans.

UnitType.Quote: To feel my touch is to feel no more.
UnitType.Backstory:
Orphanages are common in Umber. Places where children displaced by war, famine or disease stay in conditions that make the slave pits of Magnar look elegant. In most, the overseer finances the orphanage by selling the children for experiments, workers, or Sawol (an Umber holiday marked by contemplation, self-mutilation and sacrifice).
But the overseer of Adytum Orphanage turned away all such requests. All children were taken in, no matter how young or marked with disease. And none ever left, either by being sold, or by growing old. It went like this for three generations of overseers until two new orphans were brought to the orphanage only to discover that its sprawling grounds were empty. There were no children, no pedagogues or mistress's, and no overseer.
There was only water dripping everywhere, though it had not rained. And beneath the orphanage, in halls so dark that torches were as faint as distant stars there were death crystals in the walls that reflected strange images. But worst of all was the creature that still walked through those halls, still partially bound by that which held him for centuries, the demon Cnotta. And from there he wandered out into the world.

UnitType.Quote: I feed on death and thrive on sorrow.
UnitType.Backstory:
Pazuzu, Lord of Fevers. It was Curgen's brother, the Drednir known as Kir-Tion, who first summoned these creatures (known variously as Drednii, or Demons) to Elemental. Upon the very altar where Josryn the Elder received Great Ereog's blessing, Kir-Tion first bound and then sacrificed the Princess Lansa to open a portal to the outer planes... and through that portal came these monsters and their brethren (it should be noted that there are some channelers who believe that the Drednii are simply death magic made flesh, and not separate, sentient creatures). All demons draw their strength from devouring the life-force of other beings.
The horns of these creatures are often used in various alchemical remedies and magical experiments, and are extremely valuable.

UnitType.Quote: I sense a power in you - a power I would take.
UnitType.Backstory:
These beings were once men, channelers who desired knowledge of the darkest arts - the spells which layfolk call Death Magic. They sought out the master of such spells, the Black Sorcerer, and begged his favor. To win it, they performed acts of perversion and blasphemy near-unmentionable;
Taher the Suffering was imbued after drowning his wife and children; Galiard of Colraine was gifted after spending three days in a burning coal pit. Yet none granted apprenticeship to the Black Sorcerer regret the price they paid. These Dark Wizards, as they are called, consider themselves greater than men now.

UnitType.Quote: Many hunters have come for me, like a deer hunting a wolf.
UnitType.Backstory:
Rabisu, who dwells in Anguish. Some say Rabisu is a wild creature grown fond of the blood of men, but this is the least likely story. The favored tale is that she was once an Amarian noblewoman who was as gentle as she was plain. She wasn't ugly, merely forgettable, with mousy brown hair and eyes that were unwilling to commit to being either green or grey. And though she was often passed over by the fairer ladies of the court, she believed that her suitor would come.
Each night Rabisu prayed for her suitor, and through she sat hopefully waiting at every holiday ball and spent long hours watching the men training in the yard, she was alone. As the years went on and she grew more round than lean, her hair became tipped with gray and the ladies around her seemed to grow younger, her hope faded.
Until the night of haunted dreams when a spirit came to her, he was beautiful and as dark as the depths of a pool at night. She knew that he was not of this world, but his touch felt like the waves of the ocean, his breath like the desert wind, and she could not resist. The creature, this beautiful demon, was only free to come to her on that tragic night, but he whispered secrets to her that would allow her to summon him again. And so she did.
In the city dark things began to happen, rats began to attack men and steal food, fleas grew so common and thick that you could not open your mouth without one crawling inside and some children were born without skin. Prayers were offered at the Scrying Pool for relief or guidance, but there was no sign until a night nearly a month past the night of haunted dreams. Then the pool showed Rabisu's house with candlelight flickering within.
Together the citizens stormed to her house, they burst inside and expected to see dark magic or the worship of forbidden gods. But what they saw was much worse, the aged Rabisu in the clutches of her demonic lover in a very unnatural form. The demon fled and once the citizens were past their horror and disgust they dragged Rabisu out into the plaza and drowned her in the scrying pool.
Rabisu fought and screamed that they hadn't cared about her, that they had left her ignored, alone and suffering, and that she didn't care about them. It was the last thing she said as she was finally held under. Shocked by their actions the citizens returned to their homes and the demon returned to where her corpse floated in the water. He called to her, awakened her, and transformed her into something far more terrible than he, more than the callousness or fear of the citizens or the lifelong anguish of gentle Rabisu.

Tym was an alchemist that was impressive in almost every area except for this height. A deficiency he planned to fix with a permanent growth potion. The potion did cause him to grow, but instead of each part of him becoming 50% larger his entire skeleton grew many times over, and the rest of him, skin, muscle and nerves stayed exactly the same size. It was a painful, but mercifully brief, transformation.
That would have been the end of Tym's story and his bones would have been little more than a curiosity until a necromancer happened across them. Now a skeleton that towers over, well... towers, wanders the land destroying buildings like a child playing with blocks.
